titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Clementine Lasar-Studwell scrapbook 1977.147
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-09-21 13:54:05 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The scrapbook documents Clementine Lasar-Studwell's career as a vocalist from 1870-1876 and includes concert programs, news clippings of concert announcements, and reviews.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of William J. Studwell, date unknown.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Clementine Lasar-Studwell was a vocalist from Brooklyn, having made her debut New York City performance as Clementine Lassar in 1871 at Association Hall. In addition to performing throughout New York City and Brooklyn during the 1870s, she also sang in church choirs and concerts throughout New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and Massachusetts, and became the featured soprano at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn in 1873. In 1880 Ms. Lasar was married and thereafter performed under her married name, Clementine Lasar-Studwell. She was the daughter of noted organist Sigismond Lasar.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Clementine Lasar-Studwell scrapbook, 1977.147, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Clementine Lasar-Studwell scrapbook is housed in a single bound volume and spans the period 1870 to 1876. The scrapbook documents Mrs. Lasar-Studwell's career as a vocalist during this period and includes concert programs, news clippings of concert announcements, and reviews.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain.

While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
